awd_titl_txt: RUI: Differential Response of Conifers to Drought Across Geographic Gradients
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how competition, species, and habitat interact to influence conifer tree responses to drought. This research will explore the impacts of drought in order to improve management efforts to mitigate conifer die-back and wildfire risk. Since 2010, over 52 million hectares of trees have died in California's forests due to climate change, drought, and drought-induced disturbances such as wildfire. Forest loss and wildfire trends have important implications for the health, safety, and well-being of communities in both urban and rural areas throughout the American West. The effects of how competition, species, and habitat interact geographically to influence tree responses to drought will be studied across six conifer species. This research will benefit society by providing valuable input data for potential fire risk modeling. The project will also mentor young scientists at an undergraduate institution. It will provide knowledge to land managers and regional tribes through public and educational outreach. 

This study will use the recent drought as a natural experiment to investigate conifer responses within diverse species' biogeographic distributions. The project will examine 1) how competition, species, and habitat interact to influence tree responses to drought, and 2) how drought resistance varies among diverse conifer species after years of severe drought. This study uses multiple measures of tree response for common and uncommon conifer species. This research will advance the geographic literature on forest drought responses, while also providing opportunities for students to work with an interdisciplinary research team. This study, focused in northern California and southern Oregon, will provide essential information about the potential impacts of ongoing drought to forest species in a biodiverse and culturally important region of the Pacific West. As forest mortality and drought are not issues unique to this region, findings from this work will benefit management efforts in many forest ecosystems, with implications for fire risk, human health and well-being.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Increasingly severe and prolonged droughts are contributing to tree stress and forest mortality across western North America. However, in many cases we currently have poor information concerning how drought responses in forests vary in relation to competition, climate, and site and tree characteristics. This project examined how competition, species, and habitat interact to influence tree responses to drought. Given the lack of knowledge on forest responses to recent droughts and the uncertainty in climate projections, this evaluation explored the impacts of changing climate, thereby improving adaptive management efforts to mitigate these impacts. These findings are of particular interest to a broad audience, given the epidemic drought-induced forest mortality and catastrophic wildland fires currently sweeping many areas of the western U.S. Since 2010, over 50 million hectares of trees have died in California’s forests due to climate changes, unprecedented drought, and drought-induced disturbances. These recent trends of forest loss are astounding and converge across both wildland and wildland-urban interface areas throughout California. The effects of how competition, species, and habitat interact to influence tree responses to drought have not been explicitly quantified across most conifer species’ geographic distributions. 

The study used the recent California drought as a natural experiment to investigate conifer responses at the margins of and within diverse species’ biogeographic distributions. Evaluation included 1) how competition, species, and habitat interact to influence tree responses to drought and 2) how drought resistance varies among diverse conifer species and across successive years of severe drought. This study used multiple measures (annual growth, intra-annual growth, and stable carbon isotope discrimination [Δ13C]) of tree response for common and uncommon conifer species. This research substantially advances the literature on forest drought responses in a state with epidemic forest mortality and also provided exceptional opportunities for students to work with an interdisciplinary research team. Students were full participants in field, lab, and analysis work, and contributed to reports and outreach presentations to agencies, landowners, and the general public. As local tribal councils, landowners, and subsistence users are particularly concerned about forest conditions, this project fills multiple knowledge gaps by providing essential information about the potential impacts of ongoing drought to forest species in a biodiverse and culturally important region of the Pacific West. Because forest mortality and drought are not issues unique to this region, findings from this work benefit management efforts in many forest ecosystems.  

We collected competition and tree characteristics from 540 focal trees across sites that varied from wetter to drier habitat conditions (54 sites) within six species’ ranges in northern California. Across sites, all six conifer species weathered severe (2013 – 2015) drought with reasonably high resistance and post-drought resilience. However, we found important differences in drought responses between coastal and montane species. Broadly, the two coastal species investigated (Sitka spruce and western hemlock) showed consistent declines in drought resistance across drought years, whereas the four montane species investigated (Shasta fir, Brewer spruce, sugar pine, and western white pine) maintained high drought resistance across drought years. The four montane species illustrated a greater importance of site conditions on drought responses than coastal species. Our findings show differential risk for drought stress across diverse conifers during severe drought. This work highlights the importance of site and tree characteristics in determining drought responses across cool, annually humid coastal habitats to seasonally dry montane habitats.

The broader impacts of this project fit into four categories: scientific advancement; young scientist development and mentorship at an undergraduate institution; knowledge transfer to managers and regional tribes; and public and educational outreach. Eighteen undergraduate and five graduate students from varied disciplines and diverse backgrounds received training and experience that promoted both interest and knowledge of the natural sciences. Investigators coordinated with local and regional stakeholders to communicate and transfer findings through meetings, presentations, discussions, field visits, webinars, publications, datasets, and a website. The study, products, and datasets are useful to researchers, resource and land managers, foresters, ecologists, biologists, geographers, regional tribal organizations, landowners, university students, policy makers, and other public entities.
